req_list.name: Prerequisites
req_list.explanation: The prerequisites for AB candidates are MAT 103, 104, and 202 or 204 ; COS 126; COS 217 and 226. Students should plan to take both 217 and 226 before the junior year. One or both of these are required prerequisites for all later computer science courses.

req_list.name: Calculus
req_list.explanation: COS AB candidates must also take Math 103-104 and one of Math 202 or 204.

req_list.name: Linear Algebra
req_list.explanation: COS AB candidates must also take Math 103-104 and one of Math 202 or 204.

req_list.name: Computer Science Prerequisites
req_list.explanation: The three prerequisite computer science courses introduce the core concepts and techniques of the field.

req_list.name: Core Courses
req_list.explanation: Eight additional departmental courses at or above the 300 level must be elected to fulfill the departmental requirements(link is external).  These eight courses must include two each from the following three areas:
If you take COS 510 (or 441) and COS 516 only one will count as a theory requirement.
If you take COS 433 and COS 533 only one will count as a theory requirement.

course_list: COS 425: Database and Information Management Systems

req_list.explanation: If you take COS 461 and  COS 561 only one will count as a systems requirement.
If you take COS 418 and  COS 518 only one will count as a systems requirement.

req_list.name: Applications
course_list: COS 314/MUS 314: Computer and Electronic Music through Programming, Performance, and Composition
COS 323/ORF 363: Computing and Optimization for the Physical and Social Sciences
COS 402: Machine Learning and  Artificial Intelligence
COS 435: Information Retrieval, Discovery, and Delivery
COS 455/MOL 455: Introduction to Genomics and Computational Molecular Biology

req_list.name: General
req_list.explanation:
Any computer science (COS) course at the 300 or 400 level (except independent work) counts as a computer science departmental.
Any 300- or 400- level Math or ELE or Physics or ORF course that does not duplicate COS content, Philosophy 312, MAE 345, CHM 303, ECO 312, MOL 437/NEU 437, NEU 330, and ECO 326 â€“ Economics of the Internet count as departmentals.

req_list.name: Independent Work
req_list.explanation: All A.B. concentrators engage in independent work supervised by a member of the department. A junior project normally involves the study and solution of specific problems, often associated with a research project. It may require a significant programming effort, a theoretical study involving the design and analysis of algorithms, or an applications problem in some other field. The results of these efforts must be presented in two written reports and posters that correspond to the work undertaken in each of the terms. The senior thesis may be a study in greater depth of one of the subjects considered in junior independent work, or it may deal with another aspect of computer science and its application.
